expected.message:
This rule is part of the Kubernetes [Pod Security Standards (PSS) restricted policies](https://kubernetes.io/docs/concepts/security/pod-security-standards/#restricted).   
This rule checks whether the pod is running containers with authorized additional capabilities.     
This rule fails if the `securityContext.capabilities.add` contains any capability beyond `NET_BIND_SERVICE` and if `securityContext.capabilities.drop` is not set to `ALL`.  
By default, if the `securityContext.capabilities.add` key is not set, the pod will not run with additional capabilities, and the rule will pass.   
Linux capabilities allow granting certain privileges to a container without granting any unnecessary ones intended for the root user.

rule.name: Pod should run containers with authorized additional capabilities (PSS Restricted)

rule.description:
This rule is part of the Kubernetes [Pod Security Standards (PSS) restricted policies](https://kubernetes.io/docs/concepts/security/pod-security-standards/#restricted).   
This rule checks whether the pod is running containers with authorized additional capabilities.     
This rule fails if the `securityContext.capabilities.add` contains any capability beyond `NET_BIND_SERVICE` and if `securityContext.capabilities.drop` is not set to `ALL`.  
By default, if the `securityContext.capabilities.add` key is not set, the pod will not run with additional capabilities, and the rule will pass.   
Linux capabilities allow granting certain privileges to a container without granting any unnecessary ones intended for the root user.
rule.name: Pod should run containers with authorized additional capabilities (PSS Restricted)

The root account should avoid using access keys. Since the root account has full permissions across the entire account, creating access keys for it increases the chance that they will be compromised. Instead, it is recommended to create IAM users with predefined roles.

See Cloud Configuration Rule `IAM-207` to see if the Root account's access keys are active.","id":"563ed717-4fb6-47fd-929e-9c794e201d0a","name":"Root account access keys should not exist","remediationInstructions":"Perform the following steps, while being signed in as the Root user, in order to delete the root user's access keys via AWS CLI: 
1. Use the following command to list the Root user's access keys. 
Copy the `AccessKeyId` from the output and paste it into the `access-key-id` value in the next step. 
```
aws iam list-access-keys
```
2. Use the following command to delete the access key(s). 
```
aws iam delete-access-key /
 --access-key-id <value>
```
>**Note** 
Once an access key is removed, any application using it will not work until a new one is configured for it.","shortId":"IAM-006"},"severity":"MEDIUM"}

expected.message:
This rule checks if the AWS Root Account has access keys. 
This rule fails if `AccountAccessKeysPresent` is not set to `0`. Note that it does not take into consideration the status of the keys if present. 
The root account should avoid using access keys. Since the root account has full permissions across the entire account, creating access keys for it increases the chance that they will be compromised. Instead, it is recommended to create IAM users with predefined roles.
>**Note** 
See Cloud Configuration Rule `IAM-207` to see if the Root account's access keys are active.

rule.name: Root account access keys should not exist

expected.message:
This rule checks if the Virtual Machine (VM) is stopped (and not deallocated) for at least a week. 
This rule fails if `code: PowerState/stopped` and the timestamp was more than 7 days ago. 
When you are logged in to the operating system of an Azure VM, you can issue a command to shut down the server (or via Azure CLI). This will kick you out of the OS and stop all processes but will maintain the allocated hardware (including the IP addresses currently assigned). If you find the VM in the Azure console, you will see the state listed as `Stopped`. The biggest thing you need to know about this state is that **you are still being charged by the hour for this instance**. 
For cost optimization and management purposes, it is recommended to deallocate (charges no longer apply) VMs that have been stopped for more than a week.

evidence.expectedValue: The VM should be used or deallocated

rule.name: Virtual Machine should not be stopped (allocated) for more than a week

This rule fails if `code: PowerState/stopped` and the timestamp was more than 7 days ago.

If you find the VM in the Azure console, you will see the state listed as `Stopped`. The biggest thing you need to know about this state is that **you are still being charged by the hour for this instance**. 
For cost optimization and management purposes, it is recommended to deallocate (charges no longer apply) VMs that have been stopped for more than a week.
rule.name: Virtual Machine should not be stopped (allocated) for more than a week
